title: Why do some people hate musicals? - Quora

response.answer_text: I agree with what everyone else answering this question has said, and as someone who loves musicals, I can break down a number of detailed reasons that people tend to dislike them. Fairy tale musicals. A great many musicals are based directly on fairy tales that are well-known, such as The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Cinderella, and Aladdin. Even the ones that play around with plot and setting, like Wonderland and Into the Woods, still feel more like something that your 13-year-old homeschooled niece would be into than sophisticated adult productions. Fairy tales not only feel like kid stuff, but since you already know the story there seems to be little point in seeing the musical if you are looking for something nuanced and original.Musicals based on classic stories. More nuanced than fairy tales, but many of us already know what Frankenstein, Dracula, The Count Of Monte Cristo, Les Miserables, The Phantom Of the Opera, and The Scarlet Pimpernel are basically supposed to be about. Or, you know, we can read the books or watch the movies for a tenth of the price of seeing the musical. Even stuff like “Camelot” or “Spamalot” or “Baker Street,” that’s kind of a mash-up of short stories, is still something that we can probably predict the outcome of, that doesn’t feel original.Musicals based on modern books, films, and “jukebox musicals.” So you’ve decided to go outside of the fairy tale/classic lit box, and do something fresh and unpredictable, based on something that enough people care about to be curious about a musical adaptation but not enough care about to say “Oh, that again, we’ve seen it before.” Like a movie! (“Little Shop Of Horrors,” “Mean Girls,” “Heathers,” “Catch Me If You Can,” “The Wedding Singer,” And “Shrek,” to name a few.). Or a book! (“Wicked,” “Hamilton,” “Fun Home,” “Tuck Everlasting,” “The Lightning Thief”). Or a comic book! (“Fun Home” And “Death Note”). Or even a TV show! (“The Addams Family” (which was also a comic), “Happy Days,” “The Spongebob Musical”). Since they tend to choose stuff that’s not too popular, these can be very successful. But, you still have people who like the book, movie, comic, or show better, and a lot of plot details do sometimes get watered down to look better on stage or fit the musical theatre tropes that audiences have come to expect, there are still a lot of people who won’t be sold on it. And then you have jukebox musicals, in which a bunch of songs by ABBA, Queen, The Who, Green Day, Elvis, or whoever are put into a musical. Sometimes there is a unique story (“Mamma Mia!”), and sometimes the results are kind of bizarre (“We Will Rock You”). If you aren’t a huge fan of Carole King, David Bowie, Bob Dylan, or whatever artist the musical pays tribute to, you probably won’t care for a jukebox musical because they have a hard time standing on their own two feet.At the end of the day... Oh, look, something original. “Dear Evan Hansen.” “Grease.” “Anything Goes.” “In the Heights.” “Avenue Q.” But are they really all that good? Really? Since so many musicals do the same thing over and over again, is it really worth your time and money to see a supposedly “original” musical that will still probably pander to the typical Broadway audience? Plus, even if you do kind of like musicals, some of the original stuff is just plain weird. Or offensive. Or both. I mean, look at “Book of Mormon.” Think of all those “artsy, groundbreaking” types of descriptions that evoke images of subtitles, dancing naked in the woods, and creepy bird costumes. Many people are simply sick of the predictability of musicals, but not out-there enough to have a vested interest in pushing the boundaries of an art form. On top of that, among people who like musicals, you have a bunch of folks dedicated to their Classics from the Good Old Days, alongside young, forward-thinking types who want to get Outspoken and Political and Controversial and Groundbreaking. I mean…talk about worlds in tension. (Then again, that is a classic plot device of drama. How ironic. Thanks, IB English Lit HL.). So, for many people who are not particularly interested in music and dancing, musicals do not satisfy the maturity, originality, and depth of plot and character that they desire and have come to expect from other forms of entertainment.

I don’t hate them, but they aren’t my favorite form of theater (with several exceptions.) For one thing, the premise of the story in so many musicals is quite banal. Girl meets bad boy, shit happens, they end up together. The settings are childish, there’s no real conflict, no world building, no character development beyond the romance. Depending on which play we’re talking about, the music can be be very….UGH. Oklahoma! springs to mind, with excruciating rhymes and dreadful music (I know, I know, Your Mileage May Vary. It is dreadful to me.) Even a musical I am fond of, with lyrics by Cole Porter, can make me want to stab my ears out. Wunderbar! Wunderbar!We're alone and hand in gloveNot a cloud, near or farWhy, it's more than wunderbar  From: Kiss Me Kate, written by Samuel and Bella Spewack with music and lyrics by Cole Porter. That said, there are a few musicals I have enjoyed. 1776 is an annual rewatch on July 4th. Fun Home was…breathtaking. The music, which won all sorts of Tony Awards, was amazing. Nonetheless, I would not say I am a fan of musicals. That all said, why do you think people “hate” musicals? That seems hyperbolic. Most people won’t have an opinion, many people may simply not like them.
